availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Richard Taylor Jacob (Lt. Gov of KY, 1863 to 1867)

body.p: Oldham County, Kentucky, farmer, politician, and soldier. Oldham County, Kentucky, native. Son of John I. Jacob and Lucy Donald Robertson Jacob. Married to Sarah Benton Jacob on January 17, 1848. Father of Richard F. Jacob and Elizabeth B. Jacob. Married to Laura Wilson Jacob on June 15, 1865. Studied law under Nathaniel Wolfe in Louisville, Kentucky, from 1845 to 1846. Captain in the Mexican-American War. Farmer in Missouri from 1848 to 1853. Owned twelve enslaved persons in Cooper County, Missouri, in 1850. Owned twelve enslaved persons in Oldham County, Kentucky, in 1860. Member of the Kentucky House of Representatives from 1859 to 1863. Presidential elector for John C. Breckinridge in 1860. Colonel of the 9th Kentucky Volunteer Cavalry Regiment (U.S.A.) from August 22, 1862 to August 21,1863. Lieutenant governor of Kentucky under Governor Thomas E. Bramlette from 1863 to 1867. Arrested and exiled from Kentucky from November 1864 to January 1865 for anti-Lincoln political activity.
